IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9135 S1381-1169(14)00245-3 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.05.035 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Catalytic performances for DCE oxidation over CeO2–CrO x catalysts: (A) DCE conversion; (B) concentration of the byproduct C2H3Cl. Fig. 2 Conversion of DCE over the CeO2–CrO x –C catalyst as a function of time. Fig. 3 XRD patterns (A) and Pore-size distribution (B) of the CeO2–CrO x catalysts. Fig. 4 SEM photographs of CeO2–CrO x catalysts: (a) CeO2–CrO x –C; (b) CeO2–CrO x –M; (c) CeO2–CrO x –S; (d) CeO2–CrO x –H. Fig. 5 Binding energies of O 1s (A), Cr 2p (B) and Ce 3d (C) of the catalysts: (a) CeO2–CrO x –C; (b) CeO2–CrO x –M; (c) CeO2–CrO x –S; (d) CeO2–CrO x –H. Fig. 6 NH3-TPD curves of the catalysts. Fig. 7 H2-TPR curves of the catalysts. Fig. 8 DCE-TPSR profiles of CeO2–CrO x catalysts: (A) CO2; (B) HCl; (C) Cl2. Fig. 9 DRIFTS spectra of the CeO2–CrO x –C catalyst. Highly active behaviors of CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts in deep oxidation of 1,2-dichloroethane Peng Yang Zhonghua Meng Shanshan Yang Zhinan Shi Renxian Zhou ⁎ Institute of Catalysis, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou 310028, PR China Institute of Catalysis, Zhejiang University Hangzhou 310028 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 571 88273290; fax: +86 571 88273283. Graphical abstract Four CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts were synthesized by different preparation methods and investigated for deep oxidation of 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE), as a typical representative of the chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs). The results show that the CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and microemulsion methods exhibit higher catalytic activity for DCE decomposition coupled with higher selectivity to CO2 and HCl formation and only trace of chlorinated byproduct is detected, probably due to their relatively more total acidity, higher ratio of strong/weak acidity, more Cr6+ species with strong oxidizing ability and more accessible oxygen species. Moreover, higher specific surface area and wider pore-size distribution of mesopores are also favorable for the improvement of catalytic performances. Keywords Catalytic oxidation CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide Preparation method 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE) 1 Introduction Chlorinated VOCs (or CVOCs) produced from lots of industrial process can cause great threats to the environment and human health, due to their toxic, mutagenic and carcinogenic nature [1,2]. Catalytic oxidation is a cost-effective air pollutant control technology for the elimination of CVOCs with low concentration, since it can completely destroy the compounds without creating secondary pollutants that require extra disposal. Thus, highly active catalysts, which can provide alternative to the noble metal-based catalysts [3,4], are urgently required. Among the metal oxides, chromium oxide has been shown to be one of the most efficient in the total oxidation of chlorinated VOCs [5–8]. And in these catalysts, Cr (VI) species plays a major role in the process of CVOCs oxidation, leading to considerable enhancement of the reaction rate [9]. However, the loss or/and migration of active phases may be one of the main factors leading to catalyst deactivation. Moreover, the volatilization of some toxic residues (such as CrO2Cl2) and strong adsorption of HCl and/or Cl2 at low temperature may also restrict the application of the catalysts in some ways. Recent years have saw that CeO2-based mixed oxides have caused lots of attention for CVOCs decomposition, due to their special properties [10–13]. J.I. Gutiérrez-Ortiz and coworkers [10,11] have reported that CeO2–ZrO2 mixed oxides with accessible lattice oxygen and proper surface acidity represent better catalytic activity for CVOCs decomposition than pure CeO2 or ZrO2 catalyst. While X.Y. Wang et al. [12] have displayed that CeO2–MnO x catalysts also exhibit preferable activity, which can be connected to the large amounts of active oxygen species on the surface and their easiness to eliminate the chemical adsorbed chlorine species. In our previous work, we have found that the interaction between CeO2 and Cr2O3 species, along with the synergy between CeO2–Cr2O3 and USY zeolite, would enhance catalytic decomposition of CVOCs by improving the mobility of the active oxygen species and stabilizing the active components [14]. Besides, preparation methods can have significant impact on the physico-chemical properties of the materials, such as structure, redox property and acidity [15–18], which in turn affects their catalytic behaviors. In this paper, four CeO2–CrO x catalysts have been prepared by coprecipitation, sol–gel, microemulsion and homogeneous precipitation methods. It focuses on evaluating the influence of the strong interaction between CeO2 and CrO x species prepared by different methods on catalytic activity, selectivity, stability and in-situ surface reaction mechanism for DCE decomposition. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Coprecipitation method Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and Cr(NO3)3·9H2O (Ce/Cr=2:1, molar ratio) were dissolved in deionized water, and then aqueous ammonia was added dropwise into the above mixture under rigorous stirring until the final pH value reached to 9.5. The precipitate was aged at room temperature (25°C) for 12h, and then filtered and washed with deionized water. Finally, the precipitate was dried under supercritical condition in alcohol (250°C, 7.5MPa) for 3h [19]. 2.1.2 Microemulsion method Two of the same microemulsion (I and II) containing cyclohexane, butanol and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) needed to be prepared firstly. The molar ratio of [cyclohexane]:[butanol]:[CTAB] in the mixture was 34:8:1. Under vigorous stirring condition, 20ml of the premixed solution of Ce(NO3)3 and Cr(NO3)3 (Ce/Cr=2:1, molar ratio) was added into microemulsion I. Meanwhile, microemulsion II containing NH3·H2O was also pre-prepared by the same method mentioned above. Then, microemulsion I was added into microemulsion II dropwise and then this solution was stirred vigorously until it was suspended by forming colloidal particles. The precipitate was aged at 25°C for 24h, and then filtered and washed with deionized water. The obtained solid precipitate was finally dried at 110°C for 3h [20]. 2.1.3 Sol–gel method A conventional citrate sol–gel method was used. The desired citric acid (citric acid/(Ce+Cr)=2:1, molar ratio) was added into the premixed Ce(NO3)3 and Cr(NO3)3 solution (Ce/Cr=2:1, molar ratio) under stirring condition. Then, the solution was heated at 80°C until obtaining viscous gel. This gel was then dried at 110°C overnight to form spongy material, which was known as catalyst precursor [21]. 2.1.4 Homogeneous precipitation method A premixed solution of Ce(NO3)3 and Cr(NO3)3 (molar ratio of Ce/Cr=2:1) was added to urea solution (urea/(Ce+Cr)=17:1, molar ratio) under continuous stirring. This mixture was maintained at 100°C under stirring for 3h and then cooled down to 25°C. The resulting suspension was aged at 25°C for 12h. The precipitate was filtered and washed with deionized water, then dried at 110°C for 3h [22]. All the precursors prepared by different methods mentioned above were calcined in air at 500°C for 4h, and then the obtained catalysts were pelleted and sieved to 40–60 meshes (0.3–0.45mm). The catalysts prepared by coprecipitation, microemulsion, sol–gel and homogeneous precipitation methods were marked as CeO2–CrO x –C, CeO2–CrO x –M, CeO2–CrO x –S and CeO2–CrO x –H, respectively. For comparison, pure CeO2 and Cr2O3 were also prepared by the same method as CeO2–CrO x –C. 2.2 Activity measurement Catalytic activity tests were performed in a quartz, fixed bed reactor (6mm i.d.), and 500mg catalyst (40–60 meshes) was used. The feed flowing through the micro-reactor was 1000ppmv DCE with dry air as the balance gas and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was set at 15,000h−1. The gases in the outlet were analyzed by an on-line gas chromatograph at given temperatures, which was equipped with a FID detector to analyze quantitatively the organic compounds and a TCD detector for quantitative analysis of CO2 and CO. When DCE was completely destroyed, the concentrations of HCl and Cl2 were also detected according to Ref. [8,23]. All the measurements were repeated three times. Stability test for DCE destruction was performed at 275°C for 100h continuous test under the same condition as mentioned above. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured at −196°C on a Micromeritics TrisStar II 2020 apparatus. Samples were treated under vacuum condition for 3h at 200°C before measurements. The specific surface area was calculated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation, and the porous distribution of mesopores was measured by the Barrett–Joyner–Teller (BJH) method. The powder x-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of the samples were carried out on a D/Max-2550pc X-ray powder diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 250mA). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was recorded on SU 1510 apparatus. The x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 system equipped with Al Kα radiation (1486.6eV), operating at 150W and with energy pass of 20eV. Binding energies were calibrated using C 1s hydrocarbon peak at 284.6eV. The ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out by the same methods as described in Ref. [14]. Temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) was conducted under the same condition as activity measurement ([DCE]=1000ppmv, GHSV=15,000h−1). First, DCE adsorption on the catalysts was performed at 50°C. After reaching the adsorption-desorption equilibrium, the catalyst was heated from 50 to 500°C at the rate of 5°Cmin−1. The reactant (DCE), the byproduct (C2H3Cl) and the final products (HCl, Cl2 and CO2) were detected at the same time on-line by using a MS apparatus (HIDEN QJC-20). The in-situ infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments were carried out using a NICOLET 6700 FT-IR Fourier infrared spectrometer with a ZnSe window and a nitrogen-cooled mercury–cadnium–tellvride detector (MCT). All the spectra were collected in range of 4000–1200cm−1 with a scan rate of 32 times per second. The instrument resolution was 4cm−1. The spectra information of the catalysts (100mg) was detected from 50 to 400°C. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performances for DCE decomposition Fig. 1 presents the catalytic behaviors of CeO2–CrO x mixed oxides for DCE decomposition. As shown in Fig. 1(A), CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M catalysts exhibit very high catalytic activities for DCE destruction, and DCE can be completely decomposed lower than 300°C, which is obviously higher than those over CeO2–CrO x –H and CeO2–CrO x –S. The temperature is also much lower than noble metal-based [3,4], Mn-based [24] and other CeO2-based catalysts reported in previous literatures [10,11,13]. According to the values of T 90 (temperature at which 90% conversion is obtained), the sequence of catalytic activity for DCE destruction is as follows: CeO2–CrO x –C, CeO2–CrO x –M (278°C)>CeO2–CrO x –H (309°C)>CeO2–CrO x –S (353°C). Moreover, no DCE oxidation is observed before 400°C in blank experiment. Within the detection limit of FID and TCD, all these catalysts exhibit more than 99.5% selectivity to CO x (more than 99% CO2 and little CO). Trace of C2H3Cl (as the only byproduct) is detected during DCE destruction (see Fig. 1(B)), without producing any other detectable C-containing byproducts over the catalysts. Notably, the maximum concentration of C2H3Cl over CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M is obviously smaller (only 2.2ppm). This result is quite different from the situation for noble metal-based [3,4], Mn-based [24], other CeO2-based [10,11,13] and H-type zeolite-based [14,25,26] catalysts, over which substantial amounts of C2H3Cl are detected during the process of DCE oxidation. HCl and Cl2 are the final chlorinated products when DCE and C2H3Cl are completely converted, and their concentrations are measured to compare the selectivity of HCl under steady-state conditions. The values of S HCl are near 70% on all the catalysts (shown in Table 1 ), depending on the nature of Cr element. Cl balance calculation shows 15–25% less in the outlet stream than in the inlet stream, which means that there exists Cl species deposition. For catalytic oxidation of CVOCs, catalyst deactivation is still one of the obstacles for commercial applications. Based on the results mentioned above, the CeO2–CrO x –C catalyst is chosen to evaluate its stability for 100h continuous test (shown in Fig. 2 ). It shows that DCE conversion is stable over CeO2–CrO x –C at 275°C, and only a slight decrease is found after the 100h continuous test (DCE conversion falling from 87.3% to 84.2%). The slight decrease in conversion may be connected to the relatively strong adsorption of HCl and/or Cl2 produced in the process of DCE destruction on the surface of the catalysts, thus blocking the active sites, especially under lower temperature conditions [12]. However, when the temperature reaches to 300°C, the catalyst activity for DCE oxidation is recovered again and does not decrease, meaning that for the adsorbed Cl species on the active sites, its removal rate could balance the adsorbed rate dynamically. This result indicates that the CeO2–CrO x –C mixed oxide catalyst represents good stability for DCE destruction. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 XRD and N2 adsorption/desorption measurements Fig. 3 shows the results of XRD and BET measurement for CeO2–CrO x mixed oxides prepared by different methods, and XRD and BET data of all the catalysts are displayed in Table 1. From Fig. 3(A), it can be seen that obvious feature diffraction peaks of CeO2 (fluorite-like structure at 28.6, 33.0, 47.6 and 56.4°) appear on all catalysts. Except for the cerianite reflections, the catalysts also show some small peaks at 33.6, 36.3 and 54.9°, indexes of Cr2O3 crystallization. The diffraction peaks of CeO2–CrO x –M are lower in intensity but much wider than those of CeO2–CrO x –H, indicating the existence of smaller crystallites and lower crystallinity in CeO2–CrO x –M. Besides, the lattice parameters of CeO2 in the catalysts are all smaller than that of pure CeO2 (5.4133Å). According to Ref. [27], the ionic radius of Ce4+ (0.097nm) is much bigger than that of Cr3+ (0.052nm), thus the doping of Cr3+ into the fluorite lattice would result in the decrease of lattice parameter, which can be confirmed by the data shown in Table 1. And compared with other catalysts, CeO2–CrO x –M exhibits the smallest lattice parameter, indicating that more Cr3+ enters into the CeO2 lattice, which can enhance the activity and stability of the active components. As shown in Table 1, the sequence for the BET specific surface area of the catalysts is as follows: CeO2–CrO x –C>CeO2–CrO x –M>CeO2–CrO x –H>CeO2–CrO x –S, which is agreed with the sequence of catalytic activity. CeO2–CrO x –C shows the largest specific surface area, pore volume and pore size in all the catalysts, which may be attributed to the supercritical-drying procedure. From Fig. 3(B), it can be seen that the pore-size distribution for all the catalysts is not uniform. CeO2–CrO x –M and CeO2–CrO x –S show a narrower mesopores distribution, 2–5nm and 4–10nm, respectively. While CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –H show a multiple pore structure in a wider pore-size distribution range, 2–5nm and 5–100nm for CeO2–CrO x –C, as well as 2–30nm for CeO2–CrO x –H. Moreover, the distribution of micropores is observed for CeO2–CrO x –H, in which the rich micropores leading to the bigger BET specific surface area than CeO2–CrO x –S. The results indicate that the preparation methods can markedly influence the pore-size distribution of the materials, due to the differences of the formation mechanism for the precursors. Higher specific surface area, wider pore-size distribution of mesopores and stronger interaction between CrO x and CeO2 may be favorable for the improvement of the catalytic performance for DCE destruction. 3.2.2 SEM characterization Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of these samples are presented in Fig. 4 . The results indicate that the preparation methods can markedly influence the morphologies of the materials. CeO2–CrO x –C shows villiform-like and porous particles, which is quite different from other three catalysts. Supercritical drying allows full conservation of the wet precipitates texture. The supercritical liquid has no meniscus in the wet precipitate pores and does not generate the structure-damaging capillary forces. Slow release of the solvent from the high pressure vessel maintained at supercritical temperature yields aerogels. It may also be the main reasons for its increased specific surface area, pore volume and pore size. CeO2–CrO x –M and CeO2–CrO x –S show homogenous particles with spherical morphology but the later exhibits some larger particles. Sol–gel processing is characterized by the formation of stable colloidal solutions (“sol”) in the first step, followed by anisotropic condensation of colloidal particles (micelles) producing polymeric chains with entrapped solution of condensation byproducts, resulting in the formation of a “liogel” or “hydrogel” or “monolith”. Microemulsions form when a surfactant or more commonly a mixture of surfactants and co-surfactants lowers the oil/water interfacial tension to ultralow values, allowing thermal motions to spontaneously disperse the two immiscible liquids. While CeO2–CrO x –H shows snow-like particles with irregular sizes and shapes. The reason is that the ammonia is liberated homogeneously over the whole precipitation vessel when heated to 100°C, thus avoiding higher concentrations at the inlet point, as may occur if aqueous ammonia is used directly. 3.2.3 XPS characterization The surface composition and atomic ratios obtained by XPS are displayed in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . As shown in Fig. 5(A), the O 1s spectra of the samples have one peak at 529.5eV, ascribed to the lattice oxygen. Two peaks at 531.2 and 533.5eV are also observed, which can be assigned to active oxygen species and adsorbed oxygen species, and to the surface oxygen by hydroxyl species, respectively [12]. The order for the ratio values of surface oxygen/lattice oxygen is CeO2–CrO x –M (1.22)>CeO2–CrO x –C (1.12)>CeO2–CrO x –H (0.85)>CeO2–CrO x –S (0.73), which is in accordance with their catalytic activity for DCE destruction. From Fig. 5(B) and Table 2, it can be seen that the surface molar ratios of Ce/Cr for all samples are surely higher than the value of theoretical calculation (2.0), which indicates that the distribution of Cr species on the surface is different from the bulk. This means that more Cr atoms are incorporated into the bulk instead of being distributed on the surface, thus, the lattice parameter is slightly shrinked as listed in Table 1. Moreover, XPS results verify the coexistence of two kinds of Cr species (Cr3+ and Cr6+) on the surface of all the samples, which is in accordance with the results of H2-TPR measurement shown below. The sequence of the increase in the ratio of Cr3+/Cr6+ is follow as CeO2–CrO x –M<CeO2–CrO x –C<CeO2–CrO x –H<CeO2–CrO x –S, which suggests that the stronger interaction between Cr2O3 and CeO2 species would promote the formation of more Cr6+ species. According to previous literatures [9,28,29], Cr6+ species exhibits stronger oxidizing ability, further favoring CVOCs oxidation. Thus, Cr6+ species plays a vital role in the process of DCE destruction. The oxidation states of the Ce species are also analyzed by fitting the curves of Ce 3d spectra obtained from XPS measurements (shown in Fig. 5(C)). Two peaks observed at u’ (903.5–904.2eV) and v’ (885.1–885.8eV) are the characteristic of Ce3+ in CeO2, while Ce4+ is characterized by other six peaks. As shown Table 2, compared to other two samples, CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M exhibit relatively higher concentration of Ce3+ 3d5/2, which is agreed well with the results obtained from the XRD measurement. The value of Ce3+/Ce4+ decreases in the order of CeO2–CrO x –C>CeO2–CrO x –M>CeO2–CrO x –H>CeO2–CrO x –S, indicating that there exists more oxygen vacancies in CeO2 of CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M [30,31], which is favorable for improving the mobility of active oxygen species and the redox property of the catalysts. 3.2.4 NH3-TPD characterization According to some researches [32,33], acid sites are a crucial factor in the process of CVOCs decomposition. Fig. 6 displays the NH3-TPD profiles of the catalysts, and the data of the acidity distribution of the catalysts is listed in Table 3 . For all the CeO2–CrO x mixed oxides, two strong desorption peaks of NH3 (peak α and β) are observed. The peak α appears before 300°C can be assigned to the weak acid sites, and the peak β appears at higher temperature is ascribed to the strong acid sites [26]. Compared with pure CeO2 and Cr2O3, both of the strength of weak acidity and the strength of strong acidity over CeO2–CrO x mixed oxides are significantly increased, which indicates that there exists strong interaction between Ce and Cr species. It is interesting that the preparation methods influence the amount and strength of acid sites in a distinguishable way. Compared with CeO2–CrO x –M and CeO2–CrO x –S, the strength of strong acidity is evidently promoted in CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –H catalysts according to some changes in peak-temperature of peak β, especially for CeO2–CrO x –C catalyst. In addition, the amount of the strong acid sites is also increased over CeO2–CrO x –C. From Table 3, we can see that the total acidity decreases in the order as follows: CeO2–CrO x –C>CeO2–CrO x –M>CeO2–CrO x –H>CeO2–CrO x –S, while the R s/w values (the ratio of strong acids to weak acids) over CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M are also much bigger than that of CeO2–CrO x –H and CeO2–CrO x –S catalysts, which could be related to the stronger interaction between CeO2 and CrO x species over the formers. Since the catalytic activities of CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M are much higher than that of CeO2–CrO x –H and CeO2–CrO x –S, the stronger interaction between CeO2 and CrO x promotes the dehydrochlorination of DCE as well as the suitable strength and density ratio of strong to weak acidity is in favor of improving the ability for catalytic degradation of DCE. 3.2.5 H2-TPR characterization Fig. 7 shows the H2-TPR curves of the catalysts. For all the samples (except for CeO2), two peaks are observed obviously below 600°C. The one at relatively lower temperature (peak α, ∼350°C) could be assigned to the reduction of Cr6+ species to Cr2O3 [9,34], and the other at higher temperature (peak β, ∼450°C) may be related to the reduction of the highly dispersed Cr2O3 species and/or the surface oxygen species on CeO2 [34]. It is notable to noticing that compared with pure Cr2O3, the amount of Cr6+ species are significantly increased, which indicates that there exists strong interaction between Ce and Cr species. One molar Cr own 3 molar O in CrO3, while one molar Cr own 1.5 molar O in Cr2O3. Thus, the formation of CrO3 can increase the amount of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 (more Ce3+ formed), which would contribute to the mobility of active oxygen species (the reduction of CeO2 over CeO2–CrO x appears at lower temperature than that over pure CeO2). It is obvious that the preparation methods markedly influence the redox properties of the materials to different degrees. The temperature of peak α increases in the order as follows: CeO2–CrO x –C (335°C)<CeO2–CrO x –M (346°C)<CeO2–CrO x –S (350°C)<CeO2–CrO x –H (352°C). The reduction of the CrO x species in CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M catalysts appears at relatively lower temperature, which is beneficial for the destruction of the byproducts produced in the process of DCE oxidation. In addition, another peak δ appears at about 850°C, which can be assigned to the reduction of bulk oxygen [35]. The bulk oxygen is difficult to reduce and may have little effect on the catalytic oxidation of DCE. 3.2.6 DCE-TPSR The evolution of the final products (CO2, Cl2 and HCl) over CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts has been studied by the TPSR technique to trace the in-situ evolution process of the reactant, the byproducts and the final products on the surface of the catalysts. Fig. 8 (A), (B) and (C) show the concentration curves of CO2, HCl and Cl2 in effluent gases, respectively. As presented in Fig. 8(A), CO2 can be detected as low as 160°C over the catalysts, and the largest amount of CO2 is produced when the reaction temperature reaches to about 270°C. Moreover, CO2 production over CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M are increased obviously compared to that over other catalysts, especially for CeO2–CrO x –C, indicting that the stronger interaction between CrO x and CeO2 can promote the deep oxidation of DCE and improve the selectivity to CO2 formation at relatively low temperature. Moreover, in range of 160–350°C, the formation of CO2 shows good consistence with the byproduct C2H3Cl formation over the catalysts, having to do with the presence of more Cr6+ species with good redox property and strong oxidizing ability. As the temperature increases further, CO2 shows an obvious increase over the catalysts, due to the complete oxidation of DCE and C2H3Cl. As presented in Fig. 8(B) and (C), HCl (formed via the dehydrochlorination of DCE and deep oxidation of C2H3Cl) is deemed as the major final product in the range of 50–330°C, which is the preferred product other than Cl2, due to the nature of Cr element. The amount of HCl detected within the temperature range of 50–330°C follows the order of CeO2–CrO x –C>CeO2–CrO x –M>CeO2–CrO x –S>CeO2–CrO x –H. Less amount of HCl is detected over CeO2–CrO x –S and CeO2–CrO x –H, as a result of the formation of more chlorinated byproducts. As the temperature increases further, Cl2 shows an obvious increase over the catalysts, indicating that the adsorbed Cl species begins to be desorbed from the surface of the catalysts and the deep oxidation of C2H3Cl is enhanced due to the good deep oxidation ability of the catalysts at high temperature. 3.2.7 DRIFTS In situ reaction is also investigated from 50 to 400°C by FT-IR spectra technique to study the mechanism of DCE decomposition. Fig. 9 displays the DRIFTS spectra of CeO2–CrO x –C. From Fig. 9(A), in the range of 4000–2000cm−1, a weak band at about 2961cm−1 is observed at relative low temperature (50–150°C), which is assigned to the −CH2− stretching vibration. The strength of this band gets weaker as the reaction temperature increases, indicating that the absorbed DCE gradually desorbs or begins to decompose. At about 150°C, two bands at around 2958 and 2876cm−1 appear and are strengthened, which can be attributed to the −CH3 stretching vibration. Combining with the activity evaluation results, the appearance of −CH3 may be related to the formation of carbocation or byproducts, such as CH3CHO and CH3COOH, which are readily oxidized due to the strong deep oxidation ability of CeO2–CrO x –C at high temperature. Moreover, a wide band at around 3506cm−1 is ascribed to the vibrational frequencies of OH group or H2O absorbed on the surface, which can promote the adsorption and activation of DCE. From Fig. 9(B), in the range of 2000–1200cm−1, bands located at around 1232, 1284 and 1313cm−1 may be related to the deformation of −CH2− and −CH− group, indicating that DCE can be adsorped and activated at low temperature. At the same time, bands at around 1593cm−1 can be attributed to ν(CC) corresponded to the formation of the byproduct C2H3Cl. As the reaction temperature increases, the appearance of the bands at around 1375 and 1361cm−1 is ascribed to the deformation of −CH3 group. In addition, the feature bands at around 1545 and 1453cm−1 represent asymmetric/symmetric stretching, the carboxylate ν(COO−) of the acetate type. Therefore, it could be inferred that the DCE decomposition reaction, in addition to the adsorption of DCE and the formation of C2H3Cl, may also involve the formation of oxygenated species such as alkoxides and acetates. The possible mechanism for deep oxidation of DCE over acid catalysts has been reported before [36,37]. DCE decomposition goes though via the dehydrochlorination of DCE into C2H3Cl in presence of Lewis acid. Then C2H3Cl can be attacked by the nucleophilic oxygen species on the surface of the catalyst to form chlorinated alkoxide species, which is readily decomposed to generate CH3CHO, CH3COOH and CO x . Combining the in-situ reaction of DCE decomposition with the results of characterization for the catalysts, it can be deduced that the smaller concentration of the weak acid sites over CeO2–CrO x –H and CeO2–CrO x –S catalysts is not in favor of the dehydrochlorination of DCE, while the richer strong acid sites over CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M can promote the dehydrochlorination of DCE. Besides, further deep oxidation of the byproduct C2H3Cl into CO x is also enhanced over CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M (especially for CeO2–CrO x –C), due to the presence of more Cr6+ species with stronger oxidation ability, higher ratio of strong/weak acidity along with more active oxygen species possessing better mobility, resulted from the stronger interaction between CeO2 and CrO x . In general, DCE destruction is a combination of firstly acid catalysis (DCE to C2H3Cl) and further deep oxidation (C2H3Cl to CO x ), both of which can occur on the surface of Cr6+ species. Thus, Cr6+ species plays a vital role in the process of DCE destruction. 4 Conclusions Four CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by different methods and characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, SEM, XPS, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, DCE-TPSR and DRIFTS techniques. The results show that preparation method remarkably affects the configuration of active metal oxides, nature of surface strong/weak acidity, CeO2–CrO x interaction and catalytic activities for DCE destruction. CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and microemulsion methods show better catalytic activities for DCE destruction along with higher selectivity to HCl and CO2 and only trace of chlorinated byproduct is detected, due to more total acid sites, higher ratio of strong/weak acidity, more Cr6+ species with stronger oxidizing ability and more active oxygen species with better mobility. Moreover, higher specific surface area and wider pore-size distribution of mesopores are also favorable for the improvement of catalytic performance for DCE destruction. In addition, the strong interaction between CeO2 and CrOx species over CeO2–CrO x –C catalyst can enhance the stability of active components. Therefore, CeO2–CrO x –C shows good stability during the 100h continuous stability test for DCE oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Four CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts were synthesized by different preparation methods and investigated for deep oxidation of 1,2-dichloroethane (DCE), as a typical representative of the chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs). The results show that the CeO2–CrO x –C and CeO2–CrO x –M catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and microemulsion methods exhibit higher catalytic activity for DCE decomposition coupled with higher selectivity to CO2 and HCl formation and only trace of chlorinated byproduct is detected, probably due to their relatively more total acidity, higher ratio of strong/weak acidity, more Cr6+ species with strong oxidizing ability and more accessible oxygen species. Moreover, higher specific surface area and wider pore-size distribution of mesopores are also favorable for the improvement of catalytic performances.
coredata.dc:title: Highly active behaviors of CeO2–CrO x mixed oxide catalysts in deep oxidation of 1,2-dichloroethane
